review: I got this for 2 reasons. 1st my Sony str-dn840 has airplay but uses an awful high contrast graphical display with no screen saver that burns and image into my plasma tv. The Apple TV's Airplay playing capability is better. It allows browsing from its gui of networked shared libraries, and it has a nice screen saver. 2nd, the Apple tv allows for Airplay mirroring and iCloud photo sharing. This allows you to easily watch videos taken on your iDevice on the big screen, or view your iDevice photos saved to iCloud. Yes, you can do this with any tv or blu-ray player with HDMI and a Apple AV cable. However, the proprietary cable costs $50 and the Apple TV costs $85. To me its a no-brainer to by the Apple TV for this use case for an additional $35.Of course all of this assumes you are already heavily invested in the Apple universe with iPhones, iPads, Macs and iTunes, and care about watching iPhone videos and photos on your TV. There is another issue as well. Apple is a content provider though iTunes. They really don't compete with Netflix, as they don't provide a subscription service, so you get that, but they do compete with Amazon for movie rentals, so you don't get an Amazon app. You still need another device to use your Prime streaming or rent movies from Amazon which are cheaper than iTunes. Roku on the other hand isn't an Amazon competitor, so you get Prime along with many more streaming services.Performance wise, the Apple TV has plenty of storage so that buffering and streaming quality don't seem to be an issue. Also the Apple TV has some other potential. They do add content, and there is word that Apple with update the software with more app store-like functionality, so that developers can make apps for it. We'll see. For now its a good unobtrusive player, with Apple universe integration and less content than Roku or XBMC. Well, that is, unless they develop an Apple TV 3 jailbreak.One more thing. Airplay mirroring ONLY natively works with newer Macs with better graphics hardware and iOS devices. To use AIrplay mirroring on older Macs you need to buy the AirParrot app. I can attest that this works well on a ram upgraded late 2008 MBP, but it does use a lot of system resources and spins up the fan quite a bit.
